input: Richard is a patient presenting with a tick bite over his right knee sustained approximately one week ago. He reports localized warmth, erythema, edema, and a characteristic bull’s-eye rash around the right patella, accompanied by mild pain on palpation but preserved full range of motion and no difficulty ambulating. He denies systemic symptoms such as fever, chills, body aches, or respiratory complaints but notes a mild headache and general malaise since the bite. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, well-controlled on lisinopril 20 mg daily, type 2 diabetes managed with metformin 1000 mg twice daily, and arthritis. Vital signs are stable with blood pressure 122/70 mmHg, heart rate 67 bpm, and normal temperature. Physical examination reveals no lymphadenopathy or thyromegaly, clear lungs, regular heart rhythm without murmurs, and no joint pain aside from the knee findings. Laboratory workup including Lyme serologies (titer and Western blot), hemoglobin A1c, lipid panel, and basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function were ordered. The clinical picture is suggestive of early Lyme disease, and the patient was started on a 3-week course of doxycycline 100 mg twice daily with plans to monitor response and avoid intravenous antibiotics if possible. His hypertension and diabetes are currently well-managed, and he was counseled on the importance of ongoing monitoring and adherence to treatment.

input: Andrea Barnes is a 34-year-old female with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes who presents with intermittent left knee pain and episodes of sudden instability during ambulation. The pain is localized deep to the patella, occurs less than once daily, and resolves quickly without medication. She denies any trauma, injury, or mechanical symptoms such as popping. The knee examination reveals full range of motion, no tenderness, effusion, or ligamentous instability, and X-rays show no fracture or bony abnormalities. Her hypertension is well controlled on amlodipine, lisinopril 20 mg daily, and hydrochlorothiazide, with recent home blood pressure readings around 120/70 mmHg. Her diabetes management includes metformin and Farxiga; however, her fasting blood glucose has recently been slightly elevated at approximately 130 mg/dL. Physical exam also revealed a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base, prompting an echocardiogram referral. The plan includes initiating meloxicam 15 mg daily for presumed knee arthritis, considering physical therapy for muscle strengthening, continuing current antihypertensive therapy, and obtaining hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess glycemic control and cardiovascular risk.

input: Lawrence Butler is a 45-year-old male who presents with a one-week history of right medial elbow pain rated 6/10, localized to the inside of the elbow with occasional radiation into the forearm but not the shoulder. He denies any trauma or prior injury but reports recently taking up pottery during the COVID-19 pandemic, which he suspects may have contributed to his symptoms. The pain interferes with lifting and daily activities and is minimally relieved by ibuprofen. On examination, there is moderate tenderness over the medial epicondyle, pain with forearm pronation, and pain with resisted wrist flexion; supination is painless. Right elbow X-rays show no fractures or bony abnormalities. The clinical picture is consistent with right medial epicondylitis (golfer’s elbow) likely due to overuse of the wrist flexor tendons. The patient was advised to rest the elbow, avoid pottery for several weeks, use a sling during waking hours, apply ice thrice daily, and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week. Follow-up was arranged in one week to assess progress.

input: Wayne Taylor is a 66-year-old male who presents with a 3-week history of left shoulder pain without any specific injury. He reports the pain as constant and worsening, particularly exacerbated by reaching overhead, lifting objects, and lying on the affected shoulder at night. He has a history of intermittent shoulder aches but notes this episode is more severe and persistent. The patient remains active and recently engaged in basement renovation work, which may have contributed to his symptoms. He denies numbness or tingling in the upper extremities. Physical examination reveals limited active and passive range of motion of the left shoulder, tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus, intact sensation, and normal neurovascular status. Left shoulder X-rays show no fractures. The clinical impression is rotator cuff tendinopathy. The management plan includes obtaining an MRI of the left shoulder for further evaluation, referral to physical therapy for 6 to 8 weeks focusing on shoulder strengthening, continuation of acetaminophen for pain control, and consideration of corticosteroid injection if symptoms persist. The patient was educated about his condition and treatment expectations and will follow up after completing physical therapy.

input: Diana Scott is a 61-year-old female who presented with a right wrist injury sustained after slipping on stairs while carrying a laundry basket. She attempted to break her fall with outstretched arms, resulting in immediate severe pain (9/10), swelling, and numbness with tingling in the fingers of the right hand. Physical examination revealed significant tenderness, swelling, bruising, limited range of motion, pain with wrist flexion, extension, radial and ulnar deviation, and bony crepitus suggestive of a fracture. Vital signs were notable for mildly elevated blood pressure (140/70 mmHg) likely related to pain. Radiographs confirmed an extra-articular right distal radius Colles fracture with severe dorsal angulation (dinner fork deformity) and an associated ulnar styloid fracture. The patient was placed in a thumb spica brace and started on Ultram for pain control. Surgical intervention with open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) was recommended urgently to restore alignment and prevent malunion. Postoperatively, she will require an overnight hospital stay, followed by six weeks of bracing and physical therapy. The patient has a planned two-week vacation in one month, and coordination with physical therapy will determine if she can safely maintain exercise during this period. Follow-up is scheduled four weeks after surgery to assess recovery.

input: Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a longstanding history of iron deficiency anemia dating back to adolescence. She reports persistent fatigue, intermittent chills and feverish sensations, exertional dyspnea with wheezing, new-onset headaches, tingling sensations, and increased cold sensitivity. Additionally, she notes worsening anxiety and depression. Her medical history is significant for heavy menstrual bleeding until a hysterectomy in 1996. A colonoscopy performed 5–6 years ago was unremarkable. She denies cardiac devices, sleep apnea, or oxygen use. Current medications include ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12. Physical examination is unremarkable, including a non-tender abdomen. Laboratory evaluation in early 2020 showed low hemoglobin and ferritin with otherwise stable hematologic parameters. The clinical plan includes continuation of oral iron supplementation with vitamin C to enhance absorption, repeat laboratory testing after 12 weeks, and referral to hematology. Diagnostic workup with upper endoscopy and colonoscopy is scheduled to evaluate for potential gastrointestinal sources of blood loss; capsule endoscopy will be considered if initial studies are inconclusive. The patient has been advised to report any worsening symptoms promptly.

input: Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female who presents for evaluation of suspected esophagitis following an episode of sharp, substernal chest pain lasting four days in early October 2020. The pain was sudden in onset, described as sharp and localized behind the sternum, exacerbated by eating, and accompanied by dysphagia. She denied prior heartburn and was unsure if she experienced it during the episode. The patient reported significant stress related to a job transition at that time. After four days without symptom relief, she sought emergency care where cardiac workup, including labs and EKG, was normal. No medications were prescribed, and she was referred for gastroenterology evaluation. Her chest pain and dysphagia resolved spontaneously approximately three days after the ED visit and have not recurred. She denies weight changes, abdominal pain, or bowel habit alterations. Past medical history includes uterine fibroids and anemia; she underwent cholecystectomy several years prior. Physical exam revealed mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants without other abnormalities. Given her resolved symptoms and normal cardiac evaluation, differential diagnoses include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal causes, and anxiety. The clinician suspects an anxiety-related non-cardiac chest pain possibly compounded by musculoskeletal factors. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) was discussed but deferred in favor of symptom monitoring, with the patient advised to report any recurrence for further evaluation.

input: Katherine Lopez is a 22-month-old female twin born prematurely at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, diagnosed with Smith-Magenis syndrome and global developmental delays. Her birth weight was 4 pounds 8 ounces. She has a history of feeding difficulties with episodes of apnea during feeding, temperature regulation issues typical of prematurity, and severe gastroesophageal reflux managed by a gastroenterologist. She was transitioned off cow’s milk to Ripple Pea Protein milk following dietary recommendations. Katherine’s developmental milestones are delayed; she did not sit unassisted until 12 months, is currently crawling, and beginning to take steps. She receives ongoing occupational, feeding, and physical therapy, with speech therapy planned to start soon. Her medical care includes evaluations by genetics, neurology, orthopedics, ophthalmology, audiology, and nutrition specialists. The geneticist advised renal screening due to the known association of Smith-Magenis syndrome with congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract, including possible renal fusion. On examination, Katherine appeared well-nourished but slightly fussy, with microphthalmia and mild hypotonia of the upper and lower extremities; external genitalia were normal. Her mother reports 8–10 wet diapers per day and improved fluid intake. Family history is notable for a healthy twin sister without Smith-Magenis syndrome and a 9-year-old brother with autism; no family history of renal disease. A renal ultrasound was ordered to screen for congenital anomalies, with plans for follow-up based on results. The family resides in Dallas, Georgia, and follow-up will be coordinated locally.

input: Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presented with a three-month history of progressively worsening headaches described as a dull ache behind the eyes, initially mild but increasing to moderate severity (6/10). The headaches are worse in the morning, last several hours, and are refractory to acetaminophen. He also reports recent episodes of bumping into door frames but denies visual complaints, balance issues, systemic symptoms, or neurological deficits. MRI of the brain revealed a pituitary lesion causing elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. Visual field testing demonstrated bitemporal hemianopia, correlating with the chiasmal compression. Laboratory evaluation showed a low TSH with otherwise normal pituitary hormone profile and routine labs. Neurological examination was otherwise unremarkable. Given the clinical and radiographic evidence of a pituitary adenoma with optic chiasm compression and associated visual field defect, the patient was counseled regarding the risks and benefits of transsphenoidal surgical resection. He consented to surgery, and plans were made for preoperative ophthalmologic visual field testing to establish a baseline for postoperative comparison.
